title: Wednesday, 17th April 2019

We also have a BHP production update but it's rather dull. The upshot is that it's difficult to mine when there's a cyclone.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Here's RBC to summarise.

BE11:23am

Our view: Another disappointing operational quarter for BHP, albeit somewhat already in the price with the prior warning from the cyclones. Iron ore production came in 5mt lower than our expectation and was in line with shipments (we had revised shipments down by 3mt in the quarter and 3mt next quarter). This suggests the overall quarter was likely running behind even before the cyclone. This now means BHP will need to produce a record 63 mt to meet our 238mt expectation for the year (new guidance 235mt- 239mt). Cost performance is also expected to now be "below USD $15/t" vs RBC at $14.43/t. There are also overruns in costs in thermal coal - now $51/t vs. RBC at 49/t. Interestingly, despite slightly lower than forecast production met coal cost guidance remains in place. Escondida grades were weaker than we had anticipated but stronger operational performance offset the difference.

Despite operations still not hitting 100% there is an element of one-off nature impacts from the recent challenges and the company continues to invest heavily in its petroleum division, which should allow for a stabilisation of production rates in c.2021-22. There is a CEO shareholder update expected at 5:30pm Melbourne time, which is not the usual format for operational reviews. Although we will soon find out what this update entails, this could be around the sanctioning of the Jansen project or a potential update on leadership succession. With a strong balance sheet the management team does have an open canvas in regards to future strategic direction.

Although firmly priced at 6.9x 2019 EV/EBITDA, BHP's diversification and high free cash flow generation, with potential for future growth whilst maintaining cash returns, provide a relatively positive outlook for the shares, especially vs. more iron ore exposed equities like RIO or VALE.

BE11:30am

Anyway, here's what it all means via Morgan Stanley.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Bunzl has reported a weaker than expected 1Q19 trading statement, and we
expect the shares to be down this morning. Organic growth totalled ~1.5% for the
first quarter (vs. 4.3% for FY18) and ~1% from net M&A, driving overall revenue
growth to 2.5% at constant FX. At actual exchange rates, revenues grew 4% YoY.
While growth was on a tougher comp YoY (1Q18: ~6%), organic revenue slowed
in the quarter principally due to “mixed macroeconomic and market conditions”
across the various geographies. Notably in North America, Bunzl experienced
slower organic growth of ~1% as a result of lower sales in the grocery and retail
sectors (growth of ~0% to -1%), driven by lower volume growth and lack of
product price inflation. 1Q organic growth in Europe, UK & Ireland and RoW
overall was ~2%. On a FY19 basis, we expect group organic growth to now total
~1% (current MSe: +2.7%). On M&A, Bunzl announced the acquisition of
Coolpack, a Dutch distributor of specialist packaging with annual revenues of
€4m (~£3.5m). Bunzl added that the pipeline of potential acquisitions is
promising and it expects to complete further transactions over 2019.

BE11:31am

And via Goldman Sachs.

BE11:31am

We view this as a disappointing trading statement. While we expected lower organic growth for FY19 compared to FY18 following softer macro trends and tougher comps in the first quarter in the US owing to a previous business win, the slowdown is bigger than expected. We also note that the lower growth could pose a moderate downside risk to our margin assumptions in North America following negative operational leverage.

Bluesky21 Bunzl is 29% Food Service, 26% Grocery then 11% in Retail - none of these is a particularly happy market
11:31 am
BE11:32am

So ... it's a margin story as much as a sales story.

Bluesky21 (Also 12% each in Cleaning & Hygiene and Safety, which seem fine)
BE11:32am

As per Jefferies.

BE11:32am

Conclusion: There has been a slowdown across the group vs 2H18 but the slowing
in North America, driven by large and challenging segments, could lead to questions
about margin sustainability and competitive dynamics. Consensus is likely to trim
and the 20x PE rating could also come under pressure.
Detail: Group organic growth in 1Q was 1.5% (JEFe: 2%, 4Q: c2.5%). Reported revenue
growth was 4% with 1.5% from FX and 1% from M&A. The slowing from 4Q was driven
by mixed market conditions across the group. Organic revenue growth in North
America was c1% (2H18: c3.5%) due to lower sales in the grocery and retail sectors,
driven by both lack of volume growth and product price inflation. Growth in the three
other divisions was c2% (2H18: c3%). In other news, Bunzl has acquired Coolpack
with revenues of £3.5m and distributes specialist packaging in the Netherlands to
grocery and food service. In the last 12 months, Bunzl has acquired 5 businesses
with c£150m of revenue (2 this FY with c£75m).

BE11:40am

Here's Citi.

BE11:40am

Mediclinic released a trading update for the year ended 31 March 2019 guiding for adjusted EPS “around 27p” which is consistent with Consensus expectation of 26.5p and CitiE 27.1p. Mediclinic announced that that Swiss debt covenants have been re-calibrated to reflect impact of regulatory changes, materially improving headroom, which we think we be well received by the market (there was no change in interest rates/margin on the debt). Importantly, the Swiss EBITDA margin at 16% was in-line guidance which should provide further relief as we some investors thought this could be closer to 15% (or lower) this year. Similarly, guidance that the FY ‘20f Swiss margin this should fall to “around 15%” should not surprise the market. Offsetting these relative positives, is somewhat softer-than-expected FY ‘20f guidance provided for the UAE and SA, both of which we ascribe to macro conditions in those countries.

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Though this earnings preview should result in mid-single digit negative consensus revisions, we think this is outweighed by the comfort that the Swiss debt covenant news and margin performance should bring. With Mediclinic trading at a discounted valuation, we argue that the results could be a catalyst for the positive re-rating of the name. We rate Mediclinic a Buy.

BE11:41am

MDC released its FY19 trading update guiding Group margins of 17% (JPMe 16.5%) and HEPS R27 (JPMe R26.4 and consensus R26.7). Overall, this was largely in-line with sellside expectation. Importantly Hirslanden’s 2019FY margin of 16% slightly beat consensus (JPMe 15.4%, cons 15.7%) and crucially guidance for 2020FY Hirslanden EBITDA margin was set at 15% vs our est of 14.6% and our back-solved S-o-P estimate that a 10-11% margin was already being priced in by the market. Guidance for SA and MEast was weaker than expected and will likely require cuts to earnings but we would expect the positive news on SW (~50% of group EBITDA) to out way the negatives elsewhere and for MDC’s stock to react positively. We still think conditions will be tough in SW in coming periods but the doomsday scenario would now appear less likely and the material negative value per share implied by our back-solved S-o-P suggests the market has overreacted to the risks.

After a slightly disappointing start to the year the group has
today posted a reassuring update on the back of healthier trading
in Q2. H1 volumes are well ahead boosted by the Westleigh deal
which has also driven the forward order book up by 49%. The
shares have lagged the sector by c20% in the last three months
on fears over forecasts. These should be allayed and we see a
catch up for the share price in the next few months. We continue
to believe the group’s mix of Partnership and private housing will
deliver robust medium term growth and strong returns. Buy.

Bluesky21 @Forester - thanks. No doubt Iran is technologically-advanced; it just seems to be under effective international embargo on payments
11:51 am
BE11:52am

H1 Trading Update. A first half update from the group has revealed that the
business remains on track to meet consensus forecasts of c£220m (including fully
consolidated JVs). Q2 has seen better trading than Q1 with strong sales rates in
both private and affordable product ranges. H1 completions are up 43%
(Partnerships +61%, Housebuilding down 2%) at 2,362 vs our full year estimate
of +30%, albeit this includes a full six month contribution from Westleigh. The
forward order book has strengthened further to £1.03bn while the number of
open sales outlets has risen 15% to 60. Net debt was £42m.
Management change. In a separate announcement the group has announced
that Becky Worthington, the group COO, is leaving the business.
Forecasts. In light of the update we are leaving our forecasts where they are, but
it is worth highlighting that our PBT forecast of £205m translates to c£214m if
we consolidated the JVs, while consensus is c£5-10m higher on that basis.
Performance & Valuation. The shares have lagged the sector badly in 2019
with only a 5% rally vs a 25% bounce for the sector due to forecast concerns
following the "softish" Q1. With those concerns now removed we see the shares
delivering some catch up over the next 3-6 months. We continue to see the mix
of the group with its big exposure to Partnership housing as an attractive medium
term mix which is capable of delivering strong returns as well as growth.
Consequently, with an unchanged target price of 375p, we see more short-term
upside in Countryside than other housebuilders for now.

11:55 am
BE11:56am

According to this morning’s estimate from the ONS, UK inflation was 1.9% y/y in March, unchanged from February and in line with our advance expectation.

As we wrote in our preview, two effects largely cancelled each other out last month. The largest upward contribution to y/y CPI inflation came from the transport category reflecting rising fuel prices in the main. Petrol prices rose between February and March but fell compared to the same period last year.

That was cancelled to a large extent by the recreation and culture and food categories, which together subtracted just short of a percentage point off y/y inflation.

The bigger surprise this month was in RPI, which printed at 2.4% y/y with the RPI-CPI wedge narrowing to 0.5ppts from an already very low 0.6ppts last month.

The wedge is now at its narrowest since November 2013. Having been (broadly) in line with its long-run average of 0.9ppts for most of 2017 and 2018, the wedge has narrowed considerably since December. The main reason for that lies in the housing categories, in particular the ‘other housing’ category.

Along with mortgage interest payments (MiPs), RPI includes housing costs, mainly depreciation and council tax both of which are excluded from CPI.

What is driving much of the narrowing of the wedge in recent times has been the housing depreciation category, which tends to move in line with overall house price growth; as house price growth has slowed in recent months so has the RPI measure of housing depreciation. Going forward, therefore, the wedge between RPI and CPI will be heavily dependent on what happens to UK house prices.

March should have marked the last month of below-target CPI inflation for a couple of months at least. In April, the lifting of the Ofgem price cap on domestic utility bills should see CPI inflation return to above 2% y/y.

Don’t expect any of this to materially change the outlook for the BoE, however, whose hands are tied as long as the UK remains in its current Brexit limbo.

Hurricane Energy announced that the Warwick Deep 205/26b-C well has commenced drilling, which is the first of three planned wells on the Lincoln/Warwick asset.

The Warwick structure has not been penetrated by a well although the adjacent Lincoln structure was drilled and discovered to be oil bearing in 2017.

The Warwick structure has a gross best estimate recoverable resource estimate of 924 million barrels of oil and Hurricane has a 50% interest in the resource post farm-out to Spirit Energy. Hurricane is carried on the well pursuant to its farmout agreement.

Net to Hurricane, we value a success case at Warwick to amount to $3.8 billion (115.6 p/sh). This valuation is indicative of the scale of the potential prize and does not reflect commercial, funding or geological risk. We assume a $70/b Brent oil price in our valuation estimate (inflated at 1%).

We have included 10% of the full success-case value of Warwick in our target price of 119p.

The outlook for Hurricane is excellent in terms of catalysts over the course of 2019. We note that crude oil prices are strengthening and that with operational success over 2019 funding risk should be alleviated by asset de-risking. BUY.

Short-term, organic growth surprises drive share prices. Yet, we recommend a structural bias. The combined effects of a “digital revolution” and a “new consumer generation” are taking the industry by storm, and causing extreme polarisation. Brands need to innovate faster, secure tighter and cleaner distribution, defend against new entrants and retailers, upgrade management processes, and start a meaningful and exciting dialogue with consumers. This is translating into a daunting, more complex business agenda – those who stick to the beaten track, tradition and well-tried icons, fall back. We assess long-term structural winners using a proprietary framework. In this light, LVMH and Tiffany look most compelling.
